bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, January 3, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas writes about his own work with the Canal Zone Sanitary Commission.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Robert M. O'Reilly, January 3, 1905
div1.opener:
COPY.
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION.
Ancon, C. Z., January 3, 1905.
General R. M. O'Reilly,
Surgeon-General United States Army,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General:
div1.p:
Kean writes me that you wish him to give you an outline of our
conditions down here, and to make this intelligible I will review shortly the
history of the facts.

When I first came down with the Commission in April of last year, I
made a general plan at their request for what I thought would be the necessary
sanitation. The Commission at the time, took no definite action on this plan,
but when I came down in June, authorized me in a general way to get it into run-
ning order. Before starting down in June they authorized my getting certain
personnel and about $50,000.00 worth of sanitary and hospital supplies with which
to make a start.

Under this authority I came down and established a Quarantine Depart-
ment at the two points of Panama and Colon. While the Commission paid for this,
it was done only under the authority of the Panamanian Government. I inclose
you copies of decrees issued by the Panamanian Government making me Health Offi-
cer for them at the two ports and at the towns of Panama and Colon. I have
already sent you copies of the scheme which I proposed to the Commission.
I also established Health Departments for the management of the towns of Panama
and Colon under this same authority. Also a Health Organization for the Zone
between Panama and Colon and a Hospital Department for the management of the
-2-
various hospitals.

I foresaw before I left the United States that there would be great
difficulty about supplies and construction as the Commission wished me to manage
these things through other departments. I pointed out to them that in the
question of supplies, if bought by one department for the whole canal, it would
take some time for such department to get organized and that I could not get my
supplies through them until they had been organized; that if my construction was
done by the Engineering Department the same difficulties would arise until the
Engineering Department had become fully organized, and this organization for
them would take considerable time. Another great objection to such a plan as
that proposed, was that in any case where rapid executive work was necessary, as
it was in my case, I could not control. For instance, if I asked for ordinary
supplies through the ordinary routine and greater pressure was brought to bear
by some other department, this other department would be attended to first and
I would have to wait. That, if in construction, the Chief Engineer, where he
could not do all, he would naturally favor those that were most important to him.

The Commission came down in September, made a formal plan of organiza-
tion, organizing the Department as I had already established it and making a fair-
ly liberal appropriation of about a million dollars for carrying it on for a
year, but did not grant independence of action in getting supplies and doing my
own constructing.

I have used my experience in Havana and depended pretty much on the
methods down there in making my plan of organization.

We have now been running six months on this scheme and have accom-
plished, to my mind, most satisfactory results.

The Quarantine Department is in full swing and is most effectively
-3-
organized at both ports. No case of any contagion has been admitted to the
Zone in this time. I can state this positively as with our control of the situ-
ation we would know of any case occurring. I feel entirely confident that our
quarantine is as effectively managed as that in the United States.

The Hospital Departments of Panama and Colon are organized and working
effectively as far as mosquito work and the control of contagious diseases are
concerned. This is all that I am very anxious about and all that the Commis-
sion will furnish funds for at present. While I proposed to the Commission a
scheme which, if carried out, would have given us a well rounded sanitary organ-
ization, such as we had in Havana, I, myself, do not lend such great importance to
such matters as street cleaning, collection of garbage, disposal of night-soil,
& c, as long as we can do the mosquito work and have an official reporting of
contagious diseases. While this is done I am satisfied that we can control the
situation. In these two towns the disease of vital importance is Yellow Fever,
and this I believe we have under control. In the six months we have had no
cases in Colon and but 13 in Panama. No two cases of yellow fever in Panama
have occurred in the same house - that is, after fumigating there has been no
secondary case, indicating that our fumigation kills all the mosquitos and each
focus as it occurs, so that eventually we will get rid of it as we did at Havana.
Along the strip we have some three hundred men doing mosquito work and have
started a dozen or more dispensaries along the line at the little towns with the
object of treating the malarially infected natives.

While it is not so easy to put down the results of this work, I feel
confident that it is producing the results. The general opinion at all these
little places is that the work has greatly decreased the number of mosquitos.
A more important fact, however, is that we have lost from malarial fever, as yet,
-4-
no white American brought from the United States. This, I think, is saying a
great deal as compared with the former French and Railroad administrations.
To have been on the Canal Zone for six months with a considerable number of un-
acclimated Americans and to have lost not a single one from malarial fever and
but one from yellow fever is very good I think. Of course I am only speaking
of the whites from the United States. We have lost some of our Jamaican negro
employes.

In our Hospital Department we have at Ancon a fairly well equipped hos-
pital containing two hundred patients. At Miraflores we are organizing a hos-
pital for chronic cases, which has just commenced and has at present only the
lepers, but which we expect to use for all our chronic cases. We have a small
hospital of ten beds at Culebra, another at Gorgona of about the same size and ten
dispensaries at other points. At Colon Hospital we have at present forty pa-
tients, but this hospital will be brought up eventually to a capacity of three
hundred. We are able to take care of, well, all the single employes of the
Commission.

I think that we have accomplished everything which could have been ac-
complished with what has been allowed by the Commission. I would like to have
a very much more perfect organization than I have, but it is not worrying me.
I can see that we are going to get, gradually, one thing and another from the
Commission as the necessity comes to them and within two or three years will
probably have all that I originally asked for, and that we will accomplish the
great result for which we came here - to free this Zone from malaria and yellow
fever.

What I hoped and wanted when I came down here was to bring this result
about in six months rather than two or three years, but just exactly what I pre-
-5-
dicted to the Commission has come about. The big supply department has been
unable to organize with sufficient rapidity to meet my wants. So far I have
only had the supplies which I brought down with me and such things as the Panama
market could afford. My first requisition (put in in July) from the United
States is as yet unfilled.

The same thing has occurred in the Construction Department. Estimates
that were made in July for the repair of Ancon Hospital have just been begun
within the last month. The Construction Department has had a very small force
of laborers and these are used at other points for which more pressure was brought
to bear.

This, I think, will give you a very good idea of our successes and our
difficulties. I am satisfied that we have the situation under control. I be-
lieve that we have practically wiped out yellow fever and I think I see ahead the
control of malarial fever. These two diseases, I am confident, control sanita-
tion on the Isthmus.

I inclose you under separate cover, copies of my October and November
reports which will also help give an idea of our present conditions.

The Commission do not favor any laboratory down here outside of those in
the hospitals - I mean any laboratory for original research. I am inclined to
think that Surgeon General Weyman of the Public Health Service has discussed this
matter with the Commission and has offered to take the whole matter off their
hands and that his Department would assume the expense. Of this I am sorry, but
I will raise no objection to the Public Health Service provided we are entirely
separate; that is, provided there will be just such a laboratory established
here as they had at Vera Cruz and at Havana.

La Garde thinks that Carroll would like to do some yellow fever work
down here. If such is the case and you want him to come, you know I would sec-
ond your views in every possible way. If he wants to come, I think I could
have him made head of whatever laboratory we have and furnish him with an unlimit-
ed supply of human pathology, but our equipment at present is very small and
would come very slowly. But we need some one for pushing our laboratory work.

I will write you from time to time explaining little points that come
up. It will give you an idea of how things are going on.
I remain, my dear General.
div1.closer: Yours very sincerely, (Signed) W. C. Gorgas.
